ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Usually I spent less than 1 hour for our readings.
1h
1-2 hours
1 hour
1-2 hours per week

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It depends on the topic of the lecture.

I like the way that we can have all EHS students to share our ideas and have a chance to know each other. But I think the topics are too narrow and they all focused on toxicology. I think maybe we could choose our own topic that we are really interested in and it could make our seminar more interesting and helpful.
Students should suggest topics/speakers at the beginning of the year to generate more widespread interest.
The papers were great, but discussion was often hard to stimulate.
good to learn latest information in EHS
Great

I believe that this is a good course. However, I am dismayed by the amount of apathy displayed by other students. This course is supposed to be a discussion and it is tough for this to properly happen when no one talks. Other than that, good course.

not pretty good to all the EHS students. Each students have different area such like toxicology or exposure. Please let the students decide which seminar they would love to attend. It's not reasonable to set this course as required course.

I understand why it is important to make this seminar mandatory for first year EHS students. However, I do not think it is fair to make it mandatory for second-year EHS students. I'm pretty sure this is the only department at YSPH that requires its second-year students to attend weekly seminars/journal clubs. It should be optional for second-year students.
strength: it's very helpful to have a better understanding on the lectures in the following weeks.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Ying Chen  Good instructor. She explained the key points of the paper we discussed.
Instructor: Ying Chen  Dr. Chen is a good instructor and I can feel that she is also a good toxicology scientist.
Instructor: Ying Chen  Kind and responsive to student feedback.

Instructor: Ying Chen  Dr. Chen is extremely knowledgeable, and I would only suggest that she intervene more in discussion, so that discussion is more structured. The more she intervened, the more successful discussions tended to be.
Instructor: Ying Chen  NICE
Instructor: Ying Chen  very helpful instuctor

Instructor: Ying Chen  She is a good instructor. I know she wants the course to be student lead but, maybe on the days when the students don't want to talk she can do more to spur on the discussions. I am not sure what she could do to spur it on. It is just something that I had noticed.
Instructor: Ying Chen  Very helpful!
Instructor: Ying Chen  very patient and nice
Instructor: Ying Chen  good

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Good seminar, but not necessary to be required for second-year student.
It is a series of speakers and guided readings by experts in the field.
good
interesting class, help us better understand public health problems around the world.

I would recommend this course to other students. I think that this course should be taken by students who are genuinely interested in the subject matter. This would be the students who would actually participate in the discussion. This course is a brief discussion of the current topics of EHS.
for first ehs student, Yes! for second ehs student, No! Finding a full time job is more important.
good
